Introduction

Pharmacogenomics concerns how specific genotypes influence drug pharmacokinetics (eg, metabolism, excretion) and pharmacodynamics (eg, efficacy, toxicity).  In addition to traditional factors (eg, age, renal function) that affect drug response, genetic variation accounts for roughly 50% of individual differences.  Pharmacogenomics is a growing field of personalized medicine that aims to tailor drug choice to the individual.

Genomic variation



Pharmacogenes code for drug-metabolizing enzymes (eg, isoforms of enzymes in the cytochrome P450 [CYP450] superfamily of enzymes), drug targets, drug receptors, and drug transporters.  Genetic variants include single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), copy number variations (CNVs), inserts, deletions, and rearrangements.  These genetic changes can be:



  • Germline (present in every cell of the body).
  • Somatic (restricted to specific cell populations, such as clonal mutations within a tumor).


This article focuses primarily on germline variants, which are present in all cells and can therefore be detected from various samples such as a buccal swab or peripheral blood monocytes.  (Somatic variants, such as tumor-specific driver mutations, are also pharmacogenetically important but are discussed in a separate article.)

Single nucleotide polymorphisms



Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the most common form of genetic variation, involve single base pair changes:



  • Missense mutations affect drug enzyme or receptor structure and activity (if in a coding region) or expression (if in a noncoding regulator region, such as a gene promoter).
  • Nonsense mutations (eg, premature stop codon) lead to truncated, nonfunctional proteins.


For example, polymorphisms in CYP2C9 (eg, CYP2C9*2) reduce its enzyme activity, leading to slower clearance of warfarin, necessitating lower maintenance doses to avoid supratherapeutic anticoagulation (eg, bleeding).

Copy number variations



Copy number variations (CNVs) refer to multiple (ie, â‰¥3) functional gene copies beyond the 2 normal parental alleles.  Extra gene copies proportionally increase the expression levels of the drug-metabolizing enzymes or receptors they code for.



For example, CYP2D6 gene duplications lead to overexpression, resulting in an ultrarapid metabolizer (UM) phenotype.  Patients with multiple CYP2D6 copies convert codeine (prodrug) to morphine (active drug) very quickly, leading to greater analgesia but an increased risk for opioid toxicity (eg, respiratory depression).

Indels



Indels are insertions or deletions of at least one nucleotide in the pharmacogene coding sequence or regulatory region, leading to:



  • Frameshift mutations (if in coding region).
  • Aberrant splicing (if in noncoding intron region).
  • Altered expression (if in noncoding regulatory region).


For example, a small deletion in the uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1) promoter region reduces enzyme expression, impairing glucuronidation of irinotecan.  This slows its biliary elimination, raising systemic irinotecan levels and increasing adverse effects (eg, neutropenia and diarrhea).

Rearrangements



Rearrangements are large structural changes (eg, translocations, inversions, chromosomal fusions) that disrupt normal genes or generate entirely new fusion genes.  They are most relevant for tumor-specific somatic mutations, such as:



  • ALK-EML4 fusion tyrosine kinase in nonâ€“small cell lung cancer, targeted by crizotinib, ceritinib, and alectinib.
  • BCR-ABL fusion tyrosine kinase in chronic myeloid leukemia, targeted by imatinib, dasatinib, and nilotinib.
  • PML-RARÎ± fusion protein in acute promyelocytic leukemia, targeted by all-trans retinoic acid.

Other mechanisms



Beyond nuclear gene sequence changes, other variations can influence the expression of drug-metabolizing enzymes or drug receptors.  They include:



  • Epigenetic modifications (eg, DNA methylation or histone acetylation) that suppress or enhance gene expression.  These are most relevant for DNA-alkylating agents (eg, temozolomide).
  • Noncoding RNAs (eg, microRNAs) that posttranscriptionally regulate mRNA stability and translation.  They impact the efficacy of therapeutic antisense oligonucleotides (eg, nusinersen).
  • Mitochondrial DNA polymorphisms that alter cellular respiration.  These are relevant for drugs that induce oxidative stress and lactic acidosis (eg, antiretrovirals).

Pharmacokinetic consequences



Pharmacokinetics ("what the body does to the drug") concerns the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of drugs.  Genetic variants can affect pharmacokinetics by impacting:



  • Phase I metabolism (cytochrome oxidase system).
  • Phase II metabolism (conjugation enzymes).
  • Drug transporters.

Altered phase I metabolism



Phase I metabolism involves CYP450 enzymes such as CYP2C9 (eg, for warfarin), CYP2C19 (eg, for clopidogrel), CYP2D6 (eg, for codeine), and CYP3A5 (eg, for tacrolimus).  In general:



  • UMs have â‰¥3 functional alleles.
  • Rapid (normal) metabolizers have 2 functional alleles.
  • Intermediate metabolizers have 1 functional allele and 1 slow allele.
  • Poor metabolizers (PMs) have 2 slow alleles.


UM phenotypes can lead to either decreased efficacy (ie, faster clearance of active drug) or increased toxicity (ie, faster activation of prodrug).  For example, UM-CYP2D6 leads to abnormally fast conversion of codeine (prodrug) to morphine, potentially leading to opioid intoxication at standard therapeutic doses.



Conversely, PM phenotypes can lead to either decreased efficacy (ie, slower activation of prodrug) or increased toxicity (ie, slower clearance of active drug).  For example, PM-CYP2C19 leads to slower conversion of clopidogrel to its active metabolite, 2-oxo-clopidogrel, leading to a greater risk for recurrent coronary or stent thrombosis.

Altered phase II metabolism



Phase II metabolism involves hepatic conjugation enzymes (which can be identified by the suffix, "â€“transferase"), such as glucuronyl transferases (eg, UGT1A1), thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT), and N-acetyltransferase (eg, NAT2).  These enzymes typically finalize inactivation of drugs and prepare them for biliary or urinary excretion.  NAT2, in particular, is highly polymorphic:



  • Rapid (normal) acetylators have 2 normal alleles.
  • Intermediate acetylators have 1 normal allele and 1 slow allele.
  • Slow acetylators have 2 slow alleles.


Intermediate or slow acetylators have reduced drug clearance, which is especially problematic for procainamide and hydralazine (eg, accumulation increases the risk for drug-induced lupus erythematosus).

Altered transport



Drug transporters are membrane-bound proteins that mediate the uptake and efflux of drugs across cellular membranes, which influences absorption, distribution, and excretion.  Two of the most clinically relevant transporter families are:



  • P-glycoprotein (P-gp), also known as ATP-binding cassette (ABC), which affects intestinal absorption and renal excretion.  Polymorphisms are associated with altered plasma concentrations of many drugs such as digoxin and amiodarone (

  • Solute carrier (SLC) transporters, such as SLCO1B1, which facilitates uptake of drugs from the circulation into hepatocytes.  Loss of function polymorphisms in SLCO1B1 can lead to impaired statin uptake, decreasing their efficacy for dyslipidemia and increasing their systemic toxicity (eg, myopathy).

Pharmacodynamic consequences



Pharmacodynamics ("what the drug does to the body") concern interactions between a drug and its biological target (eg, receptor) and downstream effects.  Genetic variants in the drug targets can significantly change the drug response, even when pharmacokinetics are normal.  In addition, human leukocyte antigen (HLA) polymorphisms can also lead to significant immune hypersensitivity reactions.

Altered receptor/target response



Genetic polymorphisms in receptors can influence receptor expression, drug-receptor binding affinity, and signal transduction sensitivity.  Examples include:



  • Vitamin K epoxide reductase complex (VKORC1), which is inhibited by warfarin.  Polymorphisms resulting in reduced enzyme expression can increase warfarin anticoagulant effect and bleeding risk.  Such polymorphisms are prevalent among individuals of Southeast Asian descent, who often require lower doses.
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), which is targeted by channel modulators such as ivacaftor, lumacaftor, and tezacaftor.  CFTR genotype (eg, Î”F508, G551D) determines eligibility for these agents because they correct very specific changes in protein structure.
  • Beta-2 adrenergic receptor (ADRB2), which is targeted by inhaled beta-2 agonists (eg, albuterol, formoterol).  ADRB2 polymorphisms lead to decreased receptor responsiveness (eg, poor bronchodilator response in asthma), and testing may impact management (eg, higher doses of inhaled corticosteroids).

Immune hypersensitivity



Certain HLA alleles predispose individuals to immune hypersensitivity reactions to specific drugs.  The hypersensitivity is unrelated to metabolism or clearance.  Instead, it occurs because the drug is presented on a major histocompatibility complex, triggering a T-cell mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.  Examples include:



  • HLA-B*57:01 and abacavir hypersensitivity, which involves fever and multisystem inflammation.
  • HLA-B*15:02 and carbamazepine hypersensitivity, which is associated with severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs) such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), particularly in individuals of Asian descent.
  • HLA-B*58:01 and allopurinol hypersensitivity, which involves SCARs, particularly in individuals of Asian descent.


The reaction is typically severe, and rechallenge has high mortality.  Therefore, pretreatment HLA testing is required.

Clinical testing recommendations



Pharmacogenetic testing is increasingly integrated into clinical decision-making (

).  The FDA publishes pharmacogenomic guidance on each drug label based on recommendations from the Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC).  For germline variants, testing can be performed using DNA from any nucleated source (eg, buccal swab, peripheral blood monocytes).

Pretesting for safety



Certain drugs require pharmacogenetic testing prior to initiation to avoid severe or life-threatening adverse reactions:



  • Azathioprine:  Patients with TPMT deficiency are at high risk for potentially fatal myelosuppression due to an inability to detoxify azathioprine (
    figure 1
    ).  Unlike other pharmacogenomic testing, TMPT activity can be assayed with a plasma enzyme activity test rather than a DNA-based genotyping.
  • Abacavir:  The HLA-B*57:01 haplotype is associated with fatal hypersensitivity reactions.  Universal genetic screening is required prior to treatment.
  • Carbamazepine:  The HLA B*15:02 and A*31:01 haplotypes are associated with SCARs such as SJS and TEN.  Genetic testing is required in high-risk populations (ie, individuals of Asian descent).
  • Allopurinol:  The HLA B*58:02 haplotype is associated with SCARs.  Genetic testing is strongly recommended in at-risk persons (ie, individuals of Han Chinese or Thai descent).


If a high-risk genotype is detected, the drug is typically contraindicated.  Immune hypersensitivity reactions tend to be idiosyncratic (ie, occurring with any dose and at any time).  Therefore, the danger cannot be fully avoided even at reduced doses.

Pretesting for efficacy



Certain drugs require pharmacogenetic testing prior to initiation to ensure that they will be effective.  If a nonresponsive genotype is detected, the patient is typically ineligible for treatment.



If CFTR modulators (eg, ivacaftor, lumacaftor, tezacaftor) are being considered for a patient with cystic fibrosis, CFTR genotyping is required to confirm the presence of at least one FDA-approved responsive mutation prior to initiation (eg, G551D for ivacaftor).



Pharmacogenetic testing for efficacy is available for clopidogrel (and other ADP [P2Y12] antiplatelet drugs) because PMs of CYP2C19 are unable to convert the drug into its active form, leading to decreased antiplatelet activity and a higher risk for cardiovascular events (eg, stent thrombosis).  Genotype testing may be considered prior to treatment, and alternative agents (eg, prasugrel, ticagrelor) are recommended for PMs.

Posttesting



Pharmacogenomic testing may be advised in patients who exhibit unexpected responses or toxicity following drug exposure.  Depending on the results of testing, the drug may sometimes be resumed (ie, rechallenge), but with major dosage adjustments based on CPIC guidance:



  • Warfarin:  Slow variants in CYP2C9 can decrease metabolism (pharmacokinetics), and loss of VKORC1 increases sensitivity (pharmacodynamics) to warfarin, leading to increased bleeding risk.  Genotyping should be considered in patients with unexplained supratherapeutic anticoagulation (eg, high international normalized ratio) despite relatively low doses of warfarin.
  • Codeine and tramadol:  Both are metabolized to active opioids by CYP2D6.  UMs are at risk for opioid toxicity (eg, respiratory depression), whereas PMs may receive inadequate analgesia.  Genotyping should be considered in individuals with an abnormal opioid response.
  • Irinotecan:  Patients with deficient UGT1A1 have reduced glucuronidation and subsequent clearance of irinotecan (active metabolite), resulting in severe neutropenia and diarrhea.  Genotyping should be considered to determine if a dose-reduced regimen is appropriate.
  • 5-FU and other fluoropyrimidines:  Reduced dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPYD) activity leads to drug accumulation and severe adverse effects (eg, mucositis, neutropenia, neurotoxicity).  Genotyping for DPYD variants is recommended after unexpected toxicity.
  • Tacrolimus:  Patients with increased CYP3A5 expression metabolize tacrolimus more rapidly and may require higher doses to achieve therapeutic levels (eg, to prevent organ transplant rejection).

Summary



Pharmacogenomics considers how genetic variation influences drug pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics.  Genetic differences account for approximately 50% of individual variations in drug response.  Variations in drug-metabolizing enzymes (eg, cytochrome P450) and transporters (eg, P-glycoprotein) alter pharmacokinetics.  Variation in drug targets and receptors (eg, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator [CFTR]) influence pharmacodynamics.  Finally, variations in major histocompatibility (human leukocyte antigen [HLA]) alleles can be associated with severe immune hypersensitivity reactions.  Pharmacogenetic testing is recommended before initiating certain drugs to avoid serious adverse effects and ensure efficacy:



  • Universal pretreatment genotyping is recommended for azathioprine (thiopurine methyltransferase, to avoid myelosuppression), abacavir (HLA-B57, to avoid hypersensitivity), and cystic fibrosis modulators (CFTR, to ensure efficacy).
  • Selective pretreatment genotyping is recommended for carbamazepine and allopurinol in certain populations (eg, individuals of Southeast Asian descent) with high-risk HLA variants.
